title: Add Mahalanobis distance — add_mahalanobis
text: df data.frame ... Columns select .inverted Logical. TRUE, covariance matrix (p x p) distribution supposed contain inverse covariance matrix. .name name new column distance value .p name new column p-value calculation tolerance `tol` [base::solve()]

title: Add Mahalanobis distance — add_mahalanobis
code: df <- head(iris) add_mahalanobis(df, Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, Petal.Width) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species       md   p_value #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa 1.901692 0.7538342 #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa 3.634221 0.4577653 #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa 4.064753 0.3973134 #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa 4.064753 0.3973134 #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa 2.167915 0.7049075 #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa 4.166667 0.3839196 df[1, ] <- NA_real_ add_mahalanobis(df, Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, Petal.Width) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species  md   p_value #> 1           NA          NA           NA          NA    <NA>  NA        NA #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa 3.2 0.5249309 #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa 3.2 0.5249309 #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa 3.2 0.5249309 #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa 3.2 0.5249309 #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa 3.2 0.5249309

title: Print a model as an equation — coef_equation
Print a model as an equation — coef_equation
text: mod model, something `stats::coef()` can extracted named vector FUN function apply values `stats::coef(mod)`, formatting; default formats 2 significant figures trailing zeros ... Additional arguments passed `FUN`

title: Print a model as an equation — coef_equation
code: mod <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width + Petal.Length, data = iris) coef_equation(mod) #> [1] "2.2 + Sepal.Width * 0.60 + Petal.Length * 0.47" # "2.2 + Sepal.Width \* 0.60 + Petal.Length \* 0.47"

what: Optimal threshold from pROC mod — pROC_optimal_threshold
title: Optimal threshold from pROC mod — pROC_optimal_threshold
text: Find optimal threshold pROC mod

title: Optimal threshold from pROC mod — pROC_optimal_threshold
Optimal threshold from pROC mod — pROC_optimal_threshold
text: mod object class "roc" (ROC model made pROC::roc(.)) method Method determine optimal threshold ... Additional arguments passed [pROC::ci.thresholds()]

title: Optimal threshold from pROC mod — pROC_optimal_threshold
code: x <- pROC::aSAH mod <- pROC::roc(x$outcome, x$s100b, levels=c("Good", "Poor")) #> Setting direction: controls < cases  pROC_optimal_threshold(mod) #> youden: 0.205 #> Sensitivity = 0.8055556 (95% CI 0.7083333 - 0.8892361) #> Specificity = 0.6341463 (95% CI 0.4878049 - 0.7804878)

title: Plots an ROC model — pROC_quick_plot
text: Quickly plots model based liking

title: Plots an ROC model — pROC_quick_plot
code: pROC_quick_plot(   mod,   thres_method = c("youden", "closest.topleft"),   col = "blue",   ...,   boots = 0L )

title: Plots an ROC model — pROC_quick_plot
text: mod object class "roc" (ROC model made [pROC::roc()]) thres_method threshold method print col color curve ... Additional arguments passed [pROC::plot.roc()] boots Number bootstrap replications perform; < 2L perform

title: Plots an ROC model — pROC_quick_plot
text: adding bootstrapped confidence intervals, core function   `pROC:::ci.sp.roc()` replaced quicker version uses parallel   processing speed bootstraps data manipulation.   likely delay running bootstraps.

title: Plots an ROC model — pROC_quick_plot
code: if (mark::package_available("pROC")) {   x <- pROC::aSAH   mod <- pROC::roc(x$outcome, x$s100b, levels = c("Good", "Poor"))   pROC_quick_plot(mod) if (FALSE) {   pROC_quick_plot(mod, boots = 100) } } #> Setting direction: controls < cases

what: Calculate change from a visit — reference_change
title: Calculate change from a visit — reference_change
text: Calculate change visit proportion change visit

title: Calculate change from a visit — reference_change
code: change_from_reference(x, reference, point = "Baseline")  pchange_from_reference(x, reference, point = "Baseline")  prop_from_reference(x, reference, point = "Baseline")  get_reference_value(x, reference, point = "Baseline")  add_change_from_reference(   .data,   values = "value",   references = "VisitName",   point = "Baseline" )  add_pchange_from_reference(   .data,   values = "value",   references = "VisitName",   point = "Baseline" )  add_change_from_reference_wide(   .data,   point = "Baseline",   cols,   percent = FALSE,   name = c("CFB", "%CFB"),   sep = " ",   rearrange = c("end", "immediate", "after"),   collate = FALSE )

title: Calculate change from a visit — reference_change
text: x vector values character name column reference vector references (.e., visit names) character name column point scalar character reference (.e., visit) (default: `"Baseline"`) .data `data.frame` values name value column references vector column names compute differences cols character vector column names percent Logical, `TRUE` also calculate percent change name character vector append new column names.  second element used `percent = TRUE`. sep character separation new column names rearrange method change arrangement `data.frame` columns new columns added: `end` nothing append columns end; `immediate` append columns immediate `col`; `` append columns last `col` entered. collate `percent = TRUE` `rearrange = ""`; show change reference `cols` percent change.

title: Calculate change from a visit — reference_change
text: functions vectorised may used inside   (grouped) `data.frame` calculate change values. `pchange_from_reference()` calculations proportion change   reference, percentage, may need multiplied `100`   achieve . `prop_from_reference()` just alias `pchange_from_reference()`. `get_reference_value()` returns reference value vector   length `x`.  may useful creating new column based   reference value `data.frame`. `add_change_from_reference()` `add_pchange_from_reference()` take   `data.frame` append reference change values.

title: Calculate change from a visit — reference_change
code: visits <- c("Screening", "Baseline", "Week 2", "Week 4", "Week 6") values <- c(3, 2, 3, 2, 4)  df <- data.frame(   values      = values,   visits      = visits,   cfb         = change_from_reference(values, visits, "Baseline"),   pcfb        = pchange_from_reference(values, visits, "Baseline"),   p_screening = pchange_from_reference(values, visits, "Week 2"),   bl_value    = get_reference_value(values, visits) )  df #>   values    visits cfb pcfb p_screening bl_value #> 1      3 Screening   1  0.5   0.0000000        2 #> 2      2  Baseline   0  0.0  -0.3333333        2 #> 3      3    Week 2   1  0.5   0.0000000        2 #> 4      2    Week 4   0  0.0  -0.3333333        2 #> 5      4    Week 6   2  1.0   0.3333333        2 add_change_from_reference(df, "values", "visits") #>   values    visits cfb pcfb p_screening bl_value values_change #> 1      3 Screening   1  0.5   0.0000000        2             1 #> 2      2  Baseline   0  0.0  -0.3333333        2             0 #> 3      3    Week 2   1  0.5   0.0000000        2             1 #> 4      2    Week 4   0  0.0  -0.3333333        2             0 #> 5      4    Week 6   2  1.0   0.3333333        2             2 add_pchange_from_reference(df, "values", "visits") #>   values    visits cfb pcfb p_screening bl_value values_pchange #> 1      3 Screening   1  0.5   0.0000000        2            0.5 #> 2      2  Baseline   0  0.0  -0.3333333        2            0.0 #> 3      3    Week 2   1  0.5   0.0000000        2            0.5 #> 4      2    Week 4   0  0.0  -0.3333333        2            0.0 #> 5      4    Week 6   2  1.0   0.3333333        2            1.0  # Appending to a wide data.frame  df <- data.frame(    Screening = c(1, 2, 3, 4),    Baseline  = c(1, 2, 3, 4),    `Week 2`  = c(1, 2, 3, 4),    `Week 4`  = c(0, 1, 2, 1),    `Week 6`  = c(0, -1, 0, 0),    end_col   = letters[1:4],    end_col2  = letters[1:4],    check.names = FALSE )  df #>   Screening Baseline Week 2 Week 4 Week 6 end_col end_col2 #> 1         1        1      1      0      0       a        a #> 2         2        2      2      1     -1       b        b #> 3         3        3      3      2      0       c        c #> 4         4        4      4      1      0       d        d add_change_from_reference_wide(df, "Baseline", paste("Week", c(2, 4, 6))) #>   Screening Baseline Week 2 Week 4 Week 6 end_col end_col2 Week 2 CFB #> 1         1        1      1      0      0       a        a          0 #> 2         2        2      2      1     -1       b        b          0 #> 3         3        3      3      2      0       c        c          0 #> 4         4        4      4      1      0       d        d          0 #>   Week 4 CFB Week 6 CFB #> 1         -1         -1 #> 2         -1         -3 #> 3         -1         -3 #> 4         -3         -4 add_change_from_reference_wide(df, cols = paste("Week", c(2, 4, 6)),                                rearrange = "after") #>   Screening Baseline Week 2 Week 4 Week 6 Week 2 CFB Week 4 CFB Week 6 CFB #> 1         1        1      1      0      0          0         -1         -1 #> 2         2        2      2      1     -1          0         -1         -3 #> 3         3        3      3      2      0          0         -1         -3 #> 4         4        4      4      1      0          0         -3         -4 #>   end_col end_col2 #> 1       a        a #> 2       b        b #> 3       c        c #> 4       d        d add_change_from_reference_wide(df, "Baseline", paste("Week", c(2, 4, 6)),                                percent = TRUE, rearrange = "end") #>   Screening Baseline Week 2 Week 4 Week 6 end_col end_col2 Week 2 CFB #> 1         1        1      1      0      0       a        a          0 #> 2         2        2      2      1     -1       b        b          0 #> 3         3        3      3      2      0       c        c          0 #> 4         4        4      4      1      0       d        d          0 #>   Week 2 %CFB Week 4 CFB Week 4 %CFB Week 6 CFB Week 6 %CFB #> 1           0         -1  -100.00000         -1        -100 #> 2           0         -1   -50.00000         -3        -150 #> 3           0         -1   -33.33333         -3        -100 #> 4           0         -3   -75.00000         -4        -100 add_change_from_reference_wide(   df, "Baseline", paste("Week", c(2, 4, 6)),   percent = TRUE, rearrange = "end", collate = TRUE ) #>   Screening Baseline Week 2 Week 4 Week 6 end_col end_col2 Week 2 CFB #> 1         1        1      1      0      0       a        a          0 #> 2         2        2      2      1     -1       b        b          0 #> 3         3        3      3      2      0       c        c          0 #> 4         4        4      4      1      0       d        d          0 #>   Week 4 CFB Week 6 CFB Week 2 %CFB Week 4 %CFB Week 6 %CFB #> 1         -1         -1           0  -100.00000        -100 #> 2         -1         -3           0   -50.00000        -150 #> 3         -1         -3           0   -33.33333        -100 #> 4         -3         -4           0   -75.00000        -100

title: markExtra 0.1.2
text: corrects issue autoplot_table_mosaic() (#6) adds experimental cache() adds autoplot_table_mosaic() making mosaic plots tables adds min_max() normalization

title: markExtra 0.1.1
text: changes package name markExtra (#2) moves startup functions separate package (#1) props moved jordan::proportions()
